name: Katrina Trinidad
body:
# Who is Katrina Trinidad? A certified athletic trainer that was born and raised in the suburbs of Los Angeles, CA. I got the nickname "Kat" in elementary school and it has since stuck. In high school when my friends were rushing to become cheerleaders, I found that being part of another team was more rewarding to me. That's when I fell in love with athletic training. The opportunity to help people and feel like you're making a difference is why I love athletic training. And I mean love it. I studied it as an undergrad at the University of Pacific and earned my Masters of Arts in Athletic Training at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. As a graduate student, I got the chance to do research for the Matthew Gfeller Sport-Related Traumatic Brain Injury Center at UNC-CH. I got the chance to work with some of the brighest people in sport related brain injury research. Working with them was daunting until you realize that you're all working toward the same goal. To help people. I've had the chance to be a part of a team of a variety of teams. From middle school baseball, collegiate gymnastics, or professional soccer - I love to watch my athletes do what they love. I currently reside in Raleigh, NC and I'm looking for the next opportunity to grow my career. I love all things southern and traveling. When I'm not writing rehab notes or making ice bags, I like to run and try new recipes. # Why Athletic Training? Most people believe athletic trainers are there just to help athletes that get injured. But I know it's so much more than that. As an athletic trainer, my job is to not only help the injured - but prevent it in the first place. Every athlete is different. There is no one size fits all plan. You must cater to each individual's needs to get them back to what they do best. Compete. I manage the expectations of all the different people involved in sports - the athlete, the coach, the parent, the doctor, the administrator - creating relationships built on respect and trust. There are lots of challenges in being an atheletic trainer. Often times I am forced to be resourceful. Long nights. Weekends. And distinguishing between normal complaints and actual injuries. It's hard work. But the reward far outweighs the challenges. You're part of a team and every day you get a chance to help people. That is what fulfills me. That's why I am an athletic trainer. # Resume ## Certifications • Board of Certification, Certified Athletic Trainer: 2000003798
• Licensed by North Carolina Board of Athletic Trainer Examiners: 1782
• American Red Cross Instructor for CPR and AED for the Professional Rescuer
• Graston Technique Certified
• TRX Suspension Training Course (L1) Certified ## Related Experience ### Select Physical Therapy – Athletic Trainer / December 2013 – Present
Responsible for athletic event coverage with Trinity Academy, Raleigh Charter High School, and Chapel Hill Rugby. Evaluate and treat athletic injuries. Communicate with parents and coaches. Provide first aid and taping as necessary. ### Dunn Physical Therapy – Head Athletic Trainer, Carolina RailHawks / February 2013 – November 2013
Responsible for the Carolina RaliHawks of the North American Soccer League. Reported to and communicated with players, team physicians, coaches, and front office staff. Implemented rehabilitative treatment plans and responsible for day to day injury management. Developed injury tracking system and created daily treatment reports along with mid season and post season injury rates. Coordinated all workers compensation claims. Coordinated all appointments between players and medical staff during and post season. ### Select Physical Therapy – Athletic Trainer / July 2012 – February 2013
Responsible for the care of athletic injuries at Trinity School of Durham and Chapel Hill (K-12). Reported to and communicated with Athletic Team Physician, parents, and coaches. Implemented and conducted all baseline concussion testing for middle school and high school teams. Assisted in marketing and promotions for Select Physical Therapy. ### University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill – Graduate Assistant Athletic Trainer / August 2010 – May 2012
Responsible for Women’s Gymnastics and Softball. Communicated and reported to the staff athletic trainers. Assisted with the implementation of rehabilitative exercises and therapeutic modalities. Approved Clinical Instructor for undergraduate athletic training students. ### University of the Pacific – Athletic Training Student /August 2008 – May 2010
Responsible for Field Hockey, Men’s and Women’s Tennis, Baseball, Softball and at the Stockton Thunder Hockey an approved clinical site for the Pacific Athletic Training Program. Prepared athletes before practice and games with various treatments and tapings. Communicated and reported to the certified athletic trainers the status of injured athletes. ## Education University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill / August 2010 – May 2012 Master of Arts in Athletic Training University of the Pacific / August 2006 – May 2010 Bachelor of Science in Athletic Training with a minor in English ## Publication Trinidad, K., Schmidt, J., Register-Mihalik, J., Groff, D., Goto, S., and Guskiewicz, K. (2013) Predicting Clinical Concussion Measures Based on Motivation and Academic Profile. _Clinical Journal of Sports Medicine_ 23(6) 462-469. # Contact Me email: ktrinidadatc@gmail.com
